pageData.text: In this investigation, students will determine the <button class='glossary-text'>density</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>specific gravity</button> of several objects. Using knowledge of <button class='glossary-text'>isostasy</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>density stratification</button>, students also will determine the layers of a theoretical Earth.

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Density and Earth’s Structure

text: Calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>density</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>specific gravity</button> of an irregularly shaped object.
Identify and describe the compositional and mechanical layers of the earth.
Define, explain, and illustrate the relationship between density, crustal thickness, and <button class='glossary-text'>isostasy</button>.
Explain the importance of the bimodal distribution of the earth’s <button class='glossary-text'>hypsometric curve</button>.

pageData.text: One of the most worrying consequences of global climate change is sea level rise, which could potentially threaten millions of people living in coastal areas. Predicting exactly how much sea level will rise and in which areas is complicated by a number of factors related to <button class='glossary-text'>density</button> and Earth’s structure.  Sea levels rise through two main mechanisms-thermal expansion of water and increased water from melting land ice. When water increases in temperature, its density decreases and volume increases, causing sea levels to rise relative to the land area. Similarly, when land ice melts and runs into oceans, this increases the amount of water and raises sea levels. Interestingly, melting icebergs and sea ice sheets does not raise sea levels because the ice has already displaced the volume of water it would occupy once melted. However, while the water levels are changing, the land area is also changing. When ice melts off land, it changes the mass and density of the land, which can lead to isostatic rebound, or the lithospheric plate floating higher on the <button class='glossary-text'>asthenosphere</button> than before. This could potentially offset some of the effects of sea level rise. Unfortunately, these two processes rarely occur at the same rate or in the same locations, so isostatic rebound is unlikely to prevent much of the anticipated damage from sea level rise. These interconnected processes make it important to model future sea level rise to help communities prepare for coming changes.

Rising sea levels by go_greener_oz is available under CC BY-ND 2.0 at
https://www.flickr.com/photos/go_greener_oz/3046225225

pageData.desc: A sandy beach by the ocean in which are staked two signs. The sign in the background and closest to the water says 2030 sea level. The sign in the foreground and furthest from the water says 2050 sea level.
pageData.altText: A sandy beach by the ocean in which are staked two signs. The sign in the background and closest to the water says 2030 sea level. The sign in the foreground and furthest from the water says 2050 sea level.

pageData.text: is the mass of an object compared to its volume; therefore, density is how much something “weighs” per unit of its volume.

pageData.desc: Equation 1: Density equals mass divided by volume.
pageData.altText: Equation 1: Density equals mass divided by volume.

pageData.text: An object that has a large amount of mass but a comparatively small volume, such as a lead ball, would be said to have a high density, which typically means having a density of greater than 10.0 grams per milliliter (g/mL). On the other hand, if something has a small mass but a comparatively large volume, it would have a low density. A foam ball is an example of an object with a low density, which is usually somewhere slightly less than 0.05 g/mL.

Measurements of density are typically recorded in grams per milliliter (g/mL). Since water has an average density of approximately 1.0 g/mL, scientists generally use water as a reference point or standard in their discussions of density. A material with a density greater than 1.0 g/mL is often referred to as “more dense than water,” and an object with a density less than 1.0 g/mL is said to be “less dense than water.”

This comparison to water is done most directly with . The specific gravity (SpG) of a material is a comparison of its density to the density of water. The density of pure water is 1.0 g/mL. If a rock has a density of 2.65 g/mL, its specific gravity is 2.65. The units cancel out, so specific gravity is the same number as density but without any units. This shorthand helps with comparisons of materials and their relative location within the earth’s structure.

pageData.subTitle: Density Stratification, Earth Structure, and Isostasy
pageData.text: As a general rule, less dense substances rise above more dense substances, meaning less dense objects float and more dense objects sink relative to each other. This is most easily observed with liquids. Think about vegetable oil being poured in a glass of water. The vegetable oil rises to the top of the glass, and the water moves to the bottom—there is a clear, horizontal dividing line between the water and the oil. This process is called , and it happens because of density differences between materials (in this case, water and oil due to oil’s lower density of 0.93 g/mL).

A similar process happened inside our planet. Billions of years ago, when Earth was first being formed, its <button class='glossary-text'>crust</button> and internal structure were not solid like they largely are today. Early in its life, Earth was primarily composed of liquid (i.e., molten) rock at all levels, from the surface to the center. During this period of Earth’s formation, more dense material sunk toward the center of the earth and less dense material rose to the top. Then, as the earth began to cool and solidify, the materials became trapped at their new density-stratified levels in a vertical distribution that found heavy metals—like nickel, iron, and lead—concentrated at the center of the earth and lighter elements—such as silicon, sodium, and calcium—concentrated at the surface of the earth. This is not to say that lighter elements are not found at the center of the earth and heavy metals are not found at the surface, but they are in highest concentrations in their respective layers.

In fact, <button class='glossary-text'>density stratification</button> is so apparent that a cross-sectional view of the earth (Figure 1) clearly reveals a layered structure. Yet there are two basic ways that these layers can be looked at. If only the elemental composition is considered (the left side of Figure 1), then the earth’s interior is differentiated into three principal layers:

text: The , composed of rocks containing light-colored silicate (i.e., silicon-rich), low- minerals
The <button class='glossary-text'>mantle</button>, composed of rocks containing dark-colored silicate, high-density minerals
The <button class='glossary-text'>core</button>, composed of heavy metals, such as nickel and iron

pageData.desc: Figure 1: A cross-sectional view of Earth’s layers, with the elemental composition (the crust, mantle, and core) designated on the left and the physical properties (the crust, upper mantle, asthenosphere, lower mantle, outer core, and inner core) on the right
pageData.altText: Figure 1: A cross-sectional view of Earth’s layers, with the elemental composition (the crust, mantle, and core) designated on the left and the physical properties (the crust, upper mantle, asthenosphere, lower mantle, outer core, and inner core) on the right

pageData.text: If, however, the physical or mechanical properties of the rocks in the earth’s interior are considered (the right side of Figure 1), then a few additional layers result. These include the crust, <button class='glossary-text'>upper mantle</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>asthenosphere</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>lower mantle</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>outer core</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>inner core</button>.

text: The crust is the hard, brittle outer surface of the earth.
The upper mantle is the hard, brittle, and relatively cool upper portion of the mantle.
The asthenosphere (from the Greek asthenos, meaning “weak”) is a thin layer of pliable, plastically deforming rock.
The lower mantle is a thick, extremely hot layer of solid, dark-colored rocks.
The outer core is a liquid layer of heavy metal material.
The inner core is a solid layer of rock containing high levels of nickel and iron.

pageData.text: The asthenosphere is an extremely important layer in the earth’s internal structure. Because it deforms plastically (it bends and is shaped by forces such as heat and pressure) and is pliable, it acts very much like a viscous liquid. Consequently, it functions as a lubricating surface upon which the hard, brittle crust and upper mantle can move around in relation to the lower mantle. This combined layer of crust and upper mantle rock is often referred to as <button class='glossary-text'>lithosphere</button> (Figure 1).

Global-scale lithospheric movement atop the causes tremendous stress to build up in the and . This has resulted in large-scale fracturing of the into smaller sections known as lithospheric plates (Figure 2). These continent-size lithospheric plates move on top of the asthenosphere independently and pull apart from, bump into, and grind past one another in various processes generally known as .

pageData.desc: Figure 2: World map of the boundaries of the major and minor lithospheric plate, which move on top of the asthenosphere independently in various processes known as plate tectonics
pageData.altText: Figure 2: World map of the boundaries of the major and minor lithospheric plate, which move on top of the asthenosphere independently in various processes known as plate tectonics

pageData.text: Furthermore, since the asthenosphere acts very much like a viscous liquid, the lithosphere can sink down into it or rise up toward its surface based on lithospheric <button class='glossary-text'>density</button> and the thickness of the lithosphere. Figure 3 shows two arrangements of blocks on top of the asthenosphere. All the blocks on the left have the same mass but are different densities. The smaller the block, the denser it is. Since all the blocks are the same mass, the bottoms of the blocks are floating at the same depth in the asthenosphere, while the tops of the blocks are at different elevations. All the blocks in the group on the right are the same density but of different masses, resulting in blocks of different lengths. In this instance, both the bottom of the blocks and the tops are at different depths and elevations. This rising and sinking in the lithosphere based on density and mass is known as <button class='glossary-text'>isostasy</button>.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Block arrangements on top of the asthenosphere: Blocks on the left have the same mass but different densities, so the block bottoms are floating at the same depth and the tops are at different elevations. Blocks on the right are the same density but of different masses, resulting in blocks of different lengths, with both the bottoms and tops at different  depths and elevations.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Block arrangements on top of the asthenosphere: Blocks on the left have the same mass but different densities, so the block bottoms are floating at the same depth and the tops are at different elevations. Blocks on the right are the same density but of different masses, resulting in blocks of different lengths, with both the bottoms and tops at different  depths and elevations.

pageData.question: Which of the following behaves most like the lithosphere?

feedbackData.text: The combined layer of crust and upper mantle rock is often referred to as lithosphere. Both the crust and upper mantle are made up of hard, brittle material.

Consequently, it functions as a lubricating surface upon which the hard, brittle crust and upper mantle can move around in relation to the lower mantle. This combined layer of crust and upper mantle rock is often referred to as lithosphere. Global-scale lithospheric movement atop the asthenosphere causes tremendous stress to build up in the crust and upper mantle. This has resulted in large-scale fracturing of the lithosphere into smaller sections known as lithospheric plates. These continent-size lithospheric plates move on top of the asthenosphere independently and pull apart from, bump into, and grind past one another in various processes generally known as plate tectonics.

This combined layer of crust and upper mantle rock is often referred to as lithosphere. Global-scale lithospheric movement atop the asthenosphere causes tremendous stress to build up in the crust and upper mantle. This has resulted in large-scale fracturing of the lithosphere into smaller sections known as lithospheric plates. pageData.text: Oceans, Continents, and Mountains Using the basic principles of , oceanic rises lower out of the and continental lithosphere rises much higher. The oceanic lithosphere is so low in the asthenosphere that it ends up being covered with water, while the continental lithosphere rises so high that it protrudes above the waterline.

Oceanic <button class='glossary-text'>crust</button> also tends to be much thinner than continental crust. This contributes to the discussion of isostasy and lithospheric elevation in an interesting way. Consider an iceberg (Figure 4), noticing how a large percentage of the iceberg’s mass is below the waterline. The same is true of the lithosphere as it “floats” in the asthenosphere. What rides above the top of the asthenosphere is just a portion of the total lithospheric volume. In fact, the portion sunk into the asthenosphere is often the most voluminous. Since oceanic lithosphere is relatively thin and dense, only a small portion is protruding from the asthenosphere, thus contributing to an overall low elevation. On the other hand, thick, less dense continental crust will have a much higher elevation. Mountains appear most like icebergs on the asthenosphere, with deep roots sinking farther to compensate for the additional mass of the mountain.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Iceberg with an above and underwater view, showing a large percentage of the iceberg’s mass below the waterline to demonstrate how the lithosphere “floats” in the asthenosphere
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Iceberg with an above and underwater view, showing a large percentage of the iceberg’s mass below the waterline to demonstrate how the lithosphere “floats” in the asthenosphere

pageData.text: Bimodal Distribution Roughly 70% of the earth is covered by water, leaving only about 30% as exposed continental land mass. When the frequency of the crustal elevations on the earth are graphed, two distinct bell curves form. Each of these bell curves are called a mode, and the overall curve is called a bimodal distribution or (Figure 5). The upper mode peaks above sea level, and the lower curve peaks well below sea level. This demonstrates that the earth’s elevations are concentrated at two levels: one above and one below sea level. This is further evidence of because it shows that there are two general types of making up the surface layers of the earth, with one riding relatively high in the and one riding relatively low.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: A graph showing the hypsometric curve, demonstrating that the earth’s elevations are concentrated at two levels: one above and one below sea level. The graph shows the Mariana Trench at 11.04 below sea level and Mt. Everest at 8.84 km above sea level.
pageData.altText: Figure 5: A graph showing the hypsometric curve, demonstrating that the earth’s elevations are concentrated at two levels: one above and one below sea level. The graph shows the Mariana Trench at 11.04 below sea level and Mt. Everest at 8.84 km above sea level.

pageData.question: The lithosphere beneath the ocean is best described by which of the following statements?

options.text: It is relatively thin and dense.
It is relatively thick and less dense.
It is relatively thin and less dense.
It is relatively thick and dense.
It is variable in thickness and density.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Oceans form over portions of the lithosphere that are relatively thin and dense. This causes the lithosphere in these areas to protrude from the asthenosphere only a small amount, thus contributing to an overall low elevation.

pageData.question: The lithosphere that forms land masses, especially those with high elevations, is best described by which of the following statements?

options.text: It is relatively thick and less dense.
It is relatively thin and dense.
It is relatively thin and less dense.
It is relatively thick and dense.
It is variable in thickness and density.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Thick, less dense continental crust will have a much higher elevation than oceanic crust. For example, mountains appear most like icebergs on the asthenosphere, with deep roots sinking farther to compensate for the additional mass of the mountain.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Roughly 70% of the earth is covered by water, leaving only about 30% as exposed continental land mass. When the frequency of the crustal elevations on the earth is graphed, two distinct bell curves form. Each of these bell curves is called a mode, and the overall curve is called a bimodal distribution or hypsometric curve. The upper mode peaks above sea level, and the lower curve peaks well below sea level. This demonstrates that the earth’s elevations are concentrated at two levels: one above and one below sea level. This is further evidence of isostasy because it shows that there are two general types of lithosphere making up the surface layers of the earth, with one riding relatively high in the asthenosphere and one riding relatively low. What rides above the top of the asthenosphere is just a portion of the total lithospheric volume. In fact, the portion sunk into the asthenosphere is often the most voluminous. Since oceanic lithosphere is relatively thin and dense, only a small portion is protruding from the asthenosphere, thus contributing to an overall low elevation. On the other hand, thick, less dense continental crust will have a much higher elevation.

Then, you will record the initial volume in the graduated cylinder, place the rock in it and record the final volume. Next, you will calculate the volume of the rock, its density and its specific density. Finally, you will repeat the process for the steel sphere and the acrylic sphere.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) described in this section and the Activity section.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: A rock is found to have a volume of 6.1 mL and a mass of 7.8 g. What is the density of the rock?
If a rock has a density of 2.26 g/mL, what is its specific gravity?

A bottle of vinaigrette salad dressing is left on the counter for several minutes. The oil, vinegar, and spice components separate out into distinct layers in the bottle. Which of the following phenomena can be observed in the bottle?
Describing the layers of the earth by their physical properties divides the mantle into which of the following layers?

options.text: upper mantle, asthenosphere, and lower mantle
upper mantle, lithosphere, asthenosphere, and lower mantle

assestmentData.question: Approximately what percentage of the earth’s elevation falls above sea level?
Which of the following statements best describes plate tectonics?

options.text: Portions of the lithosphere rest on and move independently of the asthenosphere.
Continental crust moves independently of oceanic crust, causing seismic activity.
The lithosphere is less dense than the asthenosphere, creating a brittle crust.
The components of planet Earth are layered due to their different densities.
The lithosphere rises from or sinks into the asthenosphere based on its density.

assestmentData.question: In the hypsometric curve, what do the two peaks each represent?

options.text: The upper peak represents mean elevation on land and the lower peak represents mean depth of the ocean.
The upper peak represents mean depth of the ocean and the lower peak represents mean elevation on land.
The upper peak represents the highest elevation on land and the lower peak represents the deepest depth of the ocean.
The upper peak represents the lowest elevation on land and the lower peak represents shallowest depth of the ocean.
The upper peak represents the deepest depth of the ocean and the lower peak represents the highest elevation on land.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following materials needed for this investigation will you find in the equipment set?
Which of the following is the correct way to read a graduated cylinder?

options.text: Look at the water level at eye level and measure the volume at the bottom of the meniscus.
Look at the water level at eye level and measure the volume at the highest volume that the water touches.
Look at the water level from the top and measure the volume at the bottom of the meniscus.
Look at the water level from the base of the cylinder and measure the volume at the bottom of the meniscus.
Look at the water level from the top and measure the volume at the highest volume that the water touches.

assestmentData.question: You fill a graduated cylinder with 12.0 mL of water. You drop a rock into the cylinder and the volume rises to 21.8 mL. What is the volume of the rock?

Read through the activity.
Obtain all the materials.
In activity 1, you will use the water displacement method to determine the volume, , and of a rock sample, a steel sphere, and an acrylic sphere.

typeBefore.text: In this activity, you’ll calculate the densities of three samples. You’ll do this by using an electronic scale to find the mass of each sample and by the Water Displacement Method (Figure 6) to find the volumes. Remember, the formula for calculating is in Equation 1.

typeBefore.desc: Equation 1: Density equals mass divided by volume.
typeBefore.altText: Equation 1: Density equals mass divided by volume.

typeBefore.desc: Figure 6: Two graduated cylinders, one filled halfway with water and the other containing water and a rock, showing the change in the volume of water after the rock is added
typeBefore.altText: Figure 6: Two graduated cylinders, one filled halfway with water and the other containing water and a rock, showing the change in the volume of water after the rock is added

pageData.text: Find the mass of the rock sample using the electronic scale. Be sure to turn on the scale and press the “tare” button to zero out the scale before weighing your sample. Record the mass in grams (g) in Data Table 1.
Fill the graduated cylinder approximately halfway with water. Record the initial volume of the water (remember to read to the bottom of the meniscus) in Data Table 1.

Insert the rock sample into the graduated cylinder. Be sure that it submerges completely in the water. Be careful not to splash the water when you insert the rock sample. Record the final volume of the water (where the water level has now reached) in Data Table 1.
Subtract the initial volume from the final volume. This is the volume of your sample. Record this number in milliliters (mL) in Data Table 1.
Use the density formula to find the density of the rock sample. Record your answer in g/mL in Data Table 1.
Calculate the of the object using Equation 2:

pageData.desc: Equation 2: Specific gravity equals the density of the object divided by the density of water.
pageData.altText: Equation 2: Specific gravity equals the density of the object divided by the density of water.

pageData.text: Repeat Steps 1–6 for the steel sphere and the acrylic sphere.

text: Rinse and dry the lab equipment.
Return the materials to your equipment kit.

data.title: Asthenosphere
data.content: A thin layer of pliable, plastically deforming rock between the upper and lower mantles

data.title: Core
data.content: The innermost layer of the earth; it is composed of heavy metals, such as nickel and iron

data.title: Crust
data.content: The hard, brittle outer surface of the earth; it is composed of rocks containing light-colored silicon-rich, low-density minerals

data.title: Density
data.content: The mass of an object compared to its volume; calculated as mass divided by volume

data.title: Density stratification
data.content: The separation of substances in a mixture due to density differences

data.title: Hypsometric curve
data.content: A graph that shows the proportion of land area that exists at various elevations by plotting relative area against relative height

data.title: Inner core
data.content: A solid layer of rock containing high levels of nickel and iron in the inner portion of the core

data.title: Isostasy
data.content: The rising and sinking of the lithosphere based on its density and mass

data.title: Lithosphere
data.content: The combined layer of crust and upper mantle rock

data.title: Lower mantle
data.content: A thick, extremely hot layer of solid, dark-colored rocks in the lower portion of the mantle

data.title: Mantle
data.content: The layer of the earth composed of rocks containing dark-colored silicon-rich, high-density minerals

data.title: Outer core
data.content: A liquid layer of heavy metal material in the outer portion of the core

data.title: Plate tectonics
data.content: The movement of lithospheric plates on top of and independent from the asthenosphere

data.title: Specific gravity
data.content: A comparison of an object's density to the density of water; abbreviated SpG

data.title: Upper mantle
data.content: The hard, brittle, and relatively cool upper portion of the mantle
